# Additional Resources

## Further Reading

* [lme4 vignette for fitting linear mixed models](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/lme4/vignettes/lmer.pdf) 

* [*Mixed-Effects Models in S and S-PLUS*](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/b98882) *thee book* for **nlme**, by Jos√© C. Pinheiro and Douglas M. Bates. We used this book extensively for developing this guide. Sadly, it's both out of print and we could not find a free copy online. However, there are affordable used copies available. 

* [*Mixed Effects Models and Extensions in Ecology with R*](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-0-387-87458-6) by Alain F. Zuur, Elena N. Ieno, Neil Walker, Anatoly A. Saveliev, and Graham M. Smith. 

## Other Resources

* [Easy Stats](https://easystats.github.io/easystats/) a collection of R packages to assist in statistical modelling, with a big focus on linear models. 

* [Mixed Model CRAN Task View](https://mirror.oit.ncsu.edu/cran/web/views/MixedModels.html) a curated list of R packages relevant to mixed modelling. This is a great place to start

* [R-SIG-mixed-models](https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/r-sig-mixed-models) mailing list for help and discussion of mixed-model-related questions, course announcements, etc

* [Grammar of Experimental Designs](https://emitanaka.org/edibble-book/) by Emi Tanaka. This has a great description of basic principles of experimental design.
